page.title: 02ECOLOGYI
page.content: THE AREA IS INTENSIVELY CULTIVATED EXCEPT FOR THE PARKLAND OF TYRINGHAM & GAYHURST HALLS.HERE THE MAIN VEGETATION IS PASTURE AND WOODLAND.DOMINANT TREES PLANTED ARE BEECH,HORSE CHESTNUT, SYCAMORE,OAK,LIME,BOX,LAUREL,YEW AND CEDAR OF LEBANON.MANY ELMS TREES NOW DEAD AND HAVE NOT BEEN REPLACED.BOTH HALLS HAVE AN AVENUE OF LOMBARDYPOPLAR. AN UNUSUAL TREE IS REDWOOD. FIELD AND MEADOWS ARE BORDERED BY HEDGE ROWS.TREES & SHRUBS INCLUDE SYCAMORE, BEECH,ASH,OAK,FIELD MAPLE,ELDER, HAW- THORN AND BLACKTHORN.A WIDE VARIETY OF WILD PLANTS ARE FOUND INCLUDING WHITE CAMPION,DOGROSE,BLACKBERRY,WOODY NIGHT- SHIDE,BLACK BYRONY AND WILD PRIVET.MORE COMMON ARE SHEEP'S PARSLEY,GOOSEGRASS, DOCK,BUTTERCUP,CLOVER,NETTLES AND HOG- WEED.IN FILGRAVE ESPECIALLY THERE IS EVIDENCE OF REMOVAL OF SEVERAL HEDGEROWS IN THE LAST FEW YEARS.
